page.title: 05Farming Today :Part one
page.content:
The land,{700-1600 feet above sea {level,}is classified{grade 4 & 5}and within the less favoured area for farming by E.E.C. standards. The soil is shallow on boulder clay. Annual rainfall is 30-35 inches. The family farm remains the backbone of Welsh rural life varying in size from 10 - 200 acres. The hilly areas with enclosed rough grazing is{naturally suited to sheep {farming. Flocks number upto 500.}The sheep, mainly crossbreds for fat lamb production are found on most farms. Breeds are Suffolk x Kerry, Suffolk x Clun, Welsh x Border Leicester. Shearing is in May-June. The wool goes to South Shropshire Farmers or Welsh wool growers. The hill farms attract{subsidies.
